text.sentence: Healthcare | U.S. Health Care Managed Care fifteen March two thousand sixteen
On Monday March fourteenth afternoon, we had the opportunity to visit one of the Leon Medical Centers with the management team and members from Cigna.
The center, located in Miami Dade County, is one of the seven Leon Medical facilities that Cigna has an exclusive long term provider contract with.
The contract runs through two thousand seventeen with a five year option from Cigna .
The impressive facility is just five years old and spans eighty four thousand square feet.
The facility averages roughly one thousand two hundred encounters per day, and is responsible for more than seven thousand of the total Leon Medical Center membership of over forty five thousand.
In less than nine years of ownership, Cigna has grown the plan from just under twenty five thousand lives.
We have said previously, and reiterate today, that this is the epitome of coordinated care and speaks to the potential for superior outcomes and service that can be achieved in Medicare Advantage.
Our only hope would be that the model could be more easily exported from the current Miami Dade market.
In two thousand sixteen, Leon will be replacing two of its seven facilities with a prototype that will become the future of Leon Medical Center.
The company plans on spending as much as dollar one hundred fifty million on these capital expenditures this coming year.

Over the longer term Leon believes there will be a continued out migration of services from hospitals to outpatient facilities and believes hospitals will ultimately provide just ER and high acuity services.
Overall, we believe that the Leon model is virtually unmatched in Medicare Advantage in terms of service, quality, outcomes and certainly customer service.
The Leon family controls and operates much of the Leon Medical Center health plan with a heritage and sense of pride that only comes with a founders' mentality.
To say we were impressed with the operations, attention to detail and success would be an understatement.
Our visit underscored our view that, in HealthSpring, Cigna acquired one of the most coveted assets in the Medicare Advantage market.

The company's limited exposure to individual and small group markets leave it relatively less exposed to the minimum MLR rule.
Cigna is also expanding into international markets, a future area of less regulated growth.
Aspects of health reform are less onerous than expected, membership growth is stronger than projected, and the company can reduce its administrative cost ratio.
along with ten percent upside to estimates brings valuation to dollar one hundred eighty.
The transaction with Anthem is unsuccessful, utilization and cost trends accelerate, and Cigna is unable to improve its relative cost structure.
ten percent downside to estimates along with a forward P/E multiple of fourteen.sevenx

On Monday afternoon, we had the opportunity to visit one of the Leon Medical Centers with the management team and members from Cigna.
The center, located in Miami Dade County, is one of the seven Leon Medical facilities that Cigna has an exclusive long term provider contract with.
The contract runs through two thousand seventeen with a five year option from Cigna .
The impressive facility is just five years old and spans eighty four thousand square feet.
The facility averages roughly one thousand two hundred encounters per day, and is responsible for more than seven thousand of the total Leon Medical Center membership of over forty five thousand.
In less than nine years of ownership, Cigna has grown the plan from just under twenty five thousand lives.
The center maintains a service model that was actually modelled in part with the Ritz Carlton experience, and provides a very welcome atmosphere for Cigna's enrolees.

Additionally, Leon Medical Centers has received recognition in many industry reports including Health Affairs as one of the best examples in the nation for producing high quality care at reduced costs, and a number of academics and politicians have visited the facility to see how the facility operates.
We have said previously, and reiterate today, that this is the epitome of coordinated care and speaks to the potential for superior outcomes and service that can be achieved in Medicare Advantage.
Our only hope would be that the model could be more easily exported from the current Miami Dade market.
In two thousand sixteen, Leon will be replacing two of its seven facilities with a prototype that will become the future of Leon Medical Center.
The company plans on spending as much as dollar one hundred fifty million on these capital expenditures this coming year.
And these buildings will have the capacity to serve approximately fifteenK members.
It was very telling that the team at Leon was not satisfied with the current positioning of its delivery assets.
Despite tremendous success, and what we believe are very healthy financial results, the company is always looking to expand and improve.
In addition, Leon is expanding its service lines to offer pain management and women's center.

Over the longer term Leon believes there will be a continued out migration of services from hospitals to outpatient facilities and believes hospitals will ultimately provide just ER and high acuity services.

Keeping with the trend, Leon's long term expansion strategy is to offer outpatient surgery, skilled nursing and nuclear medicine facilities Overall, we believe that the Leon model is virtually unmatched in Medicare Advantage in terms of service, quality, outcomes and certainly customer service.
The Leon family controls and operates much of the Leon Medical Center health plan with a heritage and sense of pride that only comes with a founders' mentality.
To say we were impressed with the operations, attention to detail and success would be an understatement.
Our visit underscored our view that, in HealthSpring, Cigna acquired one of the most coveted assets in the Medicare Advantage market.
As a reminder, on October one, two thousand seven, HealthSpring acquired Leon Medical Center Health Plans, which at the time had approximately twenty five thousand eight hundred lives.
Since two thousand seven membership has grown to over forty five thousand lives of which roughly half are dual eligibles.
Membership growth in the past year is equally driven by age ins, transfers from other plans and movements from Medicare Fee for Service .
Leon maintained ownership of the Leon Medical Center facilities, and entered a ten year agreement with Cigna HealthSpring to offer services to Medicare Advantage enrollees in the county.
The first Leon Medical Center was constructed in one thousand nine hundred ninety six, and the facilities have expanded to seven currently in the county.
After briefly losing its five Star rating in two thousand fifteen (which was primarily due to the acquisition of new
Barclays | CIGNA Corp. members from other health plans), CMS gave HealthSpring of Florida a five star rating in two thousand sixteen.
CMS gave HealthSpring an overall five star rating for the Miami plan.
In addition to exclusive access to the seven Leon Medical Centers, HealthSpring operates LivingWell Centers in Tennessee, Alabama, and Texas.
These centers model the Leon Medical Center structure, and the company has been able to leverage better cost savings by providing tailored, cost effective clinical procedures.
Lastly, with the acquisition of Bravo Health, HealthSpring now operates Advanced Care Centers .

These outpatient facilities provide on staff physician hospitalists for HealthSpring MA beneficiaries, and are capable of providing immediate acute care for many conditions, a cost effective alternative to hospital emergency roo Miss.
The Leon Medical Centers continues to provide an early glimpse into the future of payor / provider relationships under health reform.
In short, it is a tightly managed, vertically integrated care delivery model with a strong focus on customer service, which benefits from efficiency, quality and cost management more than volume.
As a starting point, relationships across the delivery system are tight knit.
Only patients enrolled with the Leon Medical Center health plan may be served within one of the facilities.
LMC has exclusive contracts with approximately seventy primary care physicians and a network of hundreds of specialists, of which many have exclusive arrangements.
Additionally, primary care physicians are compensated based on a variety of quality metrics such as utilization of care, compliance with preferred prescription drugs and outcomes.
Finally, LMC only accepts one payor Medicare which helps promote efficiency across its delivery model.
Since LMC has an exclusive relationship with Cigna, and receives capitated payments, it maintains no accounts receivable or payable balances.
That is a major differentiation point compared to other facility based companies.
The centers are able to provide eighty five percent of all procedures required by enrollees, including check ups, dental care, vision screenings, and other procedures.
For the remaining fifteen percent of events, LMC has a network of providers who perform the surgery at a contracted nearby facility.
Due to the capitated contract between HealthSpring and Leon Medical Centers, the two are able to leverage cost savings into substantial benefits for HealthSpring's MA enrollees.

For example, despite the richer benefits than FFS Medicare, LMC previously estimated the cost of covering one of its senior members is eight percent twelve percent cheaper than what it would cost the government to pay for the care itself.
LMC has previously estimated that they save the government over dollar one hundred million each year.
In terms of benefits, there are several enhancements over traditional Medicare that LMC offers seniors.

For example, LMC operates a fleet of two hundred twenty five buses that transport enrollees back and forth from their home to the center, second only to the county transportation system and provides porter services onsite which is particularly valued by members whose average age is seventy three seventy four.
LMC offers dental care for members, and performed over one hundred fifty thousand procedures in two thousand fourteen.
Each facility has an on site pharmacy with the option of home delivery for prescription drugs.
The pharmacy processes one thousand one thousand two hundred scripts per day and will deliver the drugs to a member's home by the next day if they are unable to pick it up.
In addition Leon has a state of the art pharmacy refill system which refills roughly eight thousand scripts every Monday .

There is also a health and wellness center which helps members develop customized wellness programs, a fitness and entertainment center and an education center which teach basic computer skills including a class on how to use
Finally, the center also operates a coffee and pastry lounge at no cost for members, which provides a welcoming environment and improves overall experience.
Many members visit the site daily and for some members this is their meal for the day.
Together, these examples improve benefits and save cost for members and create a superior overall patient experience.

From a business perspective, this drives extremely high retention levels, membership growth and lower costs for the facilities as patients receive preventative care that they need to avoid more costly procedures in the future.
On the benefits side, members have almost no cost sharing responsibility.
Until members pass through a maximum coverage for Pharmacy or dental there are no out of pocket expenses.
However, Cigna HealthSpring has not been immune to the Medicare reimbursement cuts, therefore consistent with the industry trends there have been benefit reductions.

For instance the maximum coverage for pharmacy declined from dollar ten thousand to dollar four thousand and for dental the coverage declined from dollar three thousand to dollar one thousand five hundred.
Looking ahead, the company plans to perfect the Leon model before looking for longerterm expansion opportunities outside of Miami Dade.
Part of perfecting this model includes two brand new medical centers which will become the future prototype of all Leon Medical Centers.
These new centers will begin operations in two thousand sixteen and are the culmination of over two decades of experience.
Over the long term Leon believes there will be a continued out migration of services from hospitals to outpatient facilities and believes hospitals will provide just ER and high acuity services.
Keeping with the trend, Leon's long term expansion strategy is to offer outpatient surgery, skilled nursing and nuclear medicine facilities.
Additionally, the expansion strategy is focused on initially targeting geographies with a large Hispanic population.
Additionally, LMC noted that it could leverage economies of scale by running several administrative operations from the Miami headquarters.

With the competitive product that HealthSpring is able to provide through its exclusive arrangement with Leon Medical Centers, the company has been able to outpace MA enrollment growth relative to peers.
Currently, Cigna has the third most MA members in Miami Dade county, following the merger of Humana and CarePlus, as well as UnitedHealth with Medica Healthcare Plans and Preferred Care.

Miami has historically had some of the best relative Medicare Advantage benefit packages due to high FFS costs in the county, making it an attractive market for MA plans that can achieve cost savings through efficiency.

Despite strong competition, HealthSpring was been able to grow membership at an annual rate of nearly seven percent since two thousand seven, when the company acquired Leon Medical Center Health Plans, which gives Cigna a strong presence in South Florida.

Overall Medicare Advantage enrollment has grown six.seven percent in the county during that time, slightly worse than UnitedHealth's pro forma enrollment, and much faster than Humana's enrollment growth.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Valuation Methodology: Our twelve month price target of dollar one hundred sixty six represents a target multiple of eighteen.twox
our two thousand sixteen Cash EPS estimate of dollar nine.ten per share and a target multiple of sixteen.ninex
our two thousand seventeen Cash EPS estimate of dollar nine.eighty per share.
Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: one) As the company reprices its unprofitable health care book, it loses large blocks of membership.
We believe that CIGNA will need to reinvigorate growth to see earnings improve.
two) The substantial spending on the transformation project will likely continue to pressure earnings.
four) CIGNA's nonhealth businesses have been somewhat spotty in performance and perform worse in a slower economy.
five) While likely not imminent, CIGNA is a natural candidate for future bidding on health plan assets up for sale.
six) There is and could continue to be near term negative sentiment toward managed care companies and concern about industry pricing trends and potential litigation noise.
